executive_summary: The Elevator Manufacturing industry is composed of companies that produce elevator cars, hoisting systems and escalators for commercial, residential and industrial buildings. Demand for this industry is largely based on trends in the Construction sector, as buildings with multiple floors typically need elevators to move people and equipment between floors quickly and safely. The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a weakened construction sector, as work-from-home capabilities and growing economic uncertainty reduced demand for new construction projects. More recently, elevated interest rates have constrained investment into construction, while manufacturing construction has benefitted from federal policies. Ultimately, revenue is set to have fallen at a five year CAGR of 0.9% to reach $4.2 billion through the end of 2024, including an expected 0.3% increase in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The 2020 pandemic had a negative effect on residential, nonresidential and industrial construction activity, harming new elevator sales. During the initial stages of the pandemic, construction and manufacturing activity faced significant slowdowns as consumer uncertainty rose. The growing popularity of work-from-home trends harmed new nonresidential construction, as many companies resorted to downsizing their office spaces. Rising interest rates, stubborn inflation and swelling economic uncertainty prevent construction activity from recovering, harming elevator manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Accessibility Regulations Lead to a Boost in Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) sets standards for what buildings need elevators or other means of accessibility. Most nonresidential buildings need elevators under the ADA, forcing most new residential constructions to include elevators, supporting sales. As new accessibility standards are developed, the need for elevators and lifting equipment will rise.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Steel Prices Impact Elevator Producers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Elevator manufacturers must use high-quality materials to ensure their products are safe and efficient. The price of steel, a main input in elevator production, has endured significant volatility over recent years, as a pandemic-induced slowdown in manufacturing activity caused a significant drop in demand for steel. As the economy began to bounce back, steel prices skyrocketed. Higher steel prices and growing demand from the residential sector led to a jump in

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growing Globalization Negatively Impacts Domestic Producers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: To lower operating costs, many well-known companies have offshored production capabilities. Low-wage countries, such as China and Mexico, can produce elevators at a lower cost. Foreign manufacturers face high transportation costs due to the difficulty of shipping elevators overseas. This elevated cost stops many buyers from purchasing imported elevators. Various international conflicts have led to the appreciation of the dollar, making imported elevators more affordable for domestic buyers and boosting import penetration.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the coming years, nonresidential construction activity will likely resume as workers return to the office and investors grow confident, driving demand for elevators. The Federal Reserve will likely lower interest rates within the next five years as inflation has slowed signs of slowing, which will encourage investment. Still, interest rates will not reach pandemic-era lows.

The price of steel, having already fallen from its 2022 peak, is expected to stabilize along with broader economic conditions. Elevator manufacturers facing a more stable supply of steel (along with other upstream inputs) will be able to plan more effectively for the future.
As construction activity grows, demand for new elevators will escalate. Along with ultimately rising steel prices, the rising demand for elevators will lead to growing revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: International Competition Will Weaken Alongside The Dollar
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy stabilizes, the value of the US dollar is expected to fall. Lower domestic elevator prices benefit US manufacturers by lowering demand for imported elevators. Falling elevator prices will also boost demand for exports, particularly from countries with more accessible transportation routes, such as Mexico and Canada. Imports will continue to make up a considerable portion of the industry, although they are likely to weaken as domestic elevators become more price competitive.

industry_definition: Elevator manufacturers produce elevators for humans, freight and other transportation applications. This industry also includes the manufacturing of escalators and moving sidewalks.

threats: Demand from elevator installation and service

key_trends: Competition from foreign manufacturers is limited because of high transportation costs. Shipping elevators is a more expensive process, preventing imported elevators from taking over the market.
Well-established manufacturers have contracts in place. This, alongside prominent merger and acquisition trends, makes entering the industry more difficult for new manufacturers.

Rising interest rates are hampering construction recovery. Elevated borrowing costs deter significant investments, impacting nonresidential construction projects. The high expense of long-term loans discourages new, large-scale developments.
Volatile steel prices make life tough for manufacturers. Despite rebounding prices and demand boosting revenues, unpredictable steel costs threaten profit and make planning tricky.
Otis maintains and installs elevators for Ukrainian wind turbines. The company agreed to maintain the elevators inside wind turbines, enabling them to support sustainability trends.
Elevator producers struggle amid international construction slowdowns. US and Chinese construction activity shrunk because of growing international uncertainty, limiting demand for elevators.
Dropping nonresidential construction harms revenue. Elevated interest rates, inflation and consumer uncertainty discourage large investments, slowing down elevator sales.
Accessibility requirements boost demand for elevators. Spaces available to the public must comply with the growing regulations, creating a need for elevators.
Profit fell as the pandemic caused demand to drop. The slowdown in construction activity severely impacted new elevator sales. Profit has since begun to recover from its 2022 low.

Wage expenses are rising due to demand for highly skilled workers. Elevator manufacturers must ensure compliance with safety and efficiency standards, creating a need for knowledgeable employees in the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Industry activity in the commercial building market focuses on the construction of offices, hotels, shopping malls and other commercial
This market includes manufacturing facilities as well as wholesaling storage sites and farms. The market is mainly supplied with freight elevators.

Institutional buildings include healthcare and educational buildings. The introduction of regulations requiring all buildings with second stories to have access for disabled users has boosted demand for elevators in institutional buildings.
Elevators for residential construction projects focus on the multifamily housing market.

products_and_services.product_description: Passenger elevators are designed to move people and are characterized by larger amounts of available floor space. These include residential and commercial passenger elevators.

Freight elevators are designed to carry goods rather than passengers, as they are larger and can carry heavier loads than passenger elevators and have manually operated doors and rugged interior finishes to prevent damage.

Escalators include moving stairways and moving sidewalks. Moving stairways are most commonly used in retail spaces, such as shopping malls and department stores, while moving sidewalks are often used in airports to speed up the flow of foot traffic.

Residential elevators are commonly less costly and less complex than full commercial elevators. Limited-use, limited-application (LU/LA) elevators are primarily meant to be handicapped accessible and are exempt from many commercial regulations.

tier_1_suppliers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
Wire & Spring Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Electrical Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Hose & Belt Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Elevator Installation & Service in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Manufacturing structures often require elevators for people, materials and equipment. These structures need multiple freight elevators, which are the elevators with the highest cost. As investment in manufacturing structures grows, demand for elevators follows.

Elevators are a key addition to nonresidential buildings, such as offices, hotels and factories, as many nonresidential structures are multistory. Nonresidential buildings often require elevators for moving large loads of goods and materials. The construction of new nonresidential structures leads to higher demand for elevators used in construction and for eventual use within these structures.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Elevator Installation and Service
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industry goes hand-in-hand with the Elevator Installation and Service industry, as both industries are based around the same products. When demand for elevator installation rises, demand for elevator manufacturing follows, as installation companies need elevators to perform their services.

Steel is the most significant input cost for elevator manufacturers, as it is the main material used to produce elevators. When steel prices rise, manufacturers pass cost increases onto buyers through price increases. When elevator prices rise, so does revenue.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The strong presence of large international companies leads to higher imports, as various major manufacturers are fully or partially based overseas. International companies often only produce specific products in other countries, requiring some equipment to be imported. As offshoring and globalization trends expand, imports will continue to meet a significant portion of domestic demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A Strong US Dollar Supports Import Penetration
international_trade_points.trade_description: Over recent years, the US dollar has become comparatively more valuable than the currencies of its major trade partners, making imports more affordable for domestic consumers. An appreciating dollar has resulted in imports satisfying a larger portion of domestic demand, as lower prices act as a sales incentive.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Elevators' Dimensions and Weight Limit Trade
international_trade_points.trade_description: More than 80.0% of exports go to Canada and Mexico, mainly due to the difficulty of shipping large equipment, such as elevator cars and lifts, overseas. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) enables trade between the three countries with lower barriers as long as the elevators meet certain production criteria.

Various international conflicts, alongside the pandemic's effects on the global economy, have strengthened the US dollar. As the dollar becomes more valuable, the price of domestic elevators increases, driving up purchase costs for international markets. Stabilizing economic conditions worldwide will devalue the US dollar, effectively lowering the price of domestic elevators and slightly boosting export activity.

business_locations.location_description: Manufacturers that remain near major construction hubs, such as the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, benefit from developing strong relationships with major buyers. The Mid-Atlantic, Great Lakes and Southeast all have major ports, as they hold various large metropolitan cities.

Manufacturers that remain near major construction hubs, such as the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, benefit from developing strong relationships with major buyers. Construction activity often follows population concentrations, attracting many manufacturers to the Mid-Atlantic and the Southeast.
The Mid-Atlantic, Great Lakes and Southeast all have major ports, as they hold various large metropolitan cities.

regulations_points.regulation_title: SAFETY CODE FOR ELEVATORS AND ESCALATORS
regulations_points.regulation_description: The American National Standards Institute designed the safety code, which covers the design, construction, operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration and repair of elevators and associated parts. Elevators must meet both safety and performance standards.

The CAA requires compliance with air quality standards and empowers the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish and enforce limits on the emission of pollutants. The act establishes regulations for sulfur and nitrogen oxides and strict requirements for ozone emissions and other toxic materials.

The CWA regulates the discharge of pollutants into surface water. The act establishes a system of minimum national efficiency standards on an industry-to-industry basis, in addition to water quality standards and a discharge permit program.

Manufacturers have to ensure the safety of workers, mainly through noise and dust standards. Similarly, the act requires manufacturers to provide proper training on the use of machinery and procedure to reduce workplace risks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The elevator manufacturing industry is mature.
The industry has high revenue volatility.
The industry has low assistance level which is increasing.
The industry has high globalization level which is increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Large manufacturers benefit from economies of scale, posing a threat to smaller producers with higher operating costs. Well-established producers can also spend more on research and development and maintain positive relationships with key buyers.

Manufacturers rely heavily on labor as the design and production processes rely heavily on trained and experienced engineers. Automation trends are likely to continue, although labor will continue to be essential for elevator manufacturing.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Reaching Economies of Scale Benefits Large Manufacturers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large manufacturers can reach lower per-unit costs, leading them to be more profitable. Manufacturers with lower operating costs can pass down the cost cuts to consumers, supporting performance in the price-competitive industry. Lower per-unit costs enable larger producers to spend more on research and development, causing them to produce the most innovative elevators in the industry. Smaller and newer manufacturers tend not to have large production capacity, preventing them from achieving economies of scale.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Maintaining a Positive Relationship with Buyers is Key
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large manufacturers have positive, long-term relationships with key buyers, including large nonresidential construction companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Grow Amid Steel Volatility
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases make up the largest expense for elevator manufacturers. Inputs like steel, engines, rubber and computer components help boost this industry's purchase costs over the sector average.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Weakening Construction Activity Leads to Shrinking Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Elevator manufacturers commonly have a smaller profit margin, mainly because of their elevated input costs and need for seasoned workers.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Elevator manufacturers rely heavily on domestic construction activity, particularly in the nonresidential construction sector. Macroeconomic factors, such as corporate profit and interest rates, affect elevator manufacturers. However, the decline is mainly caused by the effects these factors have on construction investments.

volatility_points.volatility_title: US DOLLAR VALUE FLUCTUATIONS HARM DOMESTIC PRODUCERS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Imports threaten domestic manufacturers, as buyers can opt to purchase elevators and pieces from foreign manufacturers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers focus more on making elevators more efficient rather than designing new products. Recent developments include incorporating 'smart' technology into elevators, programmed to serve first the floors with the most traffic. Artificially intelligent elevators are widely adopted as they enable buildings to manage foot traffic and serve users more efficiently.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico have increased their presence in the industry.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: New elevators are exclusively sold for construction projects. As a result, manufacturers rely heavily on the health of the Construction sector (IBISWorld report 23).

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Most elevator manufacturers choose to operate near major cities with tall buildings. Mergers and acquisitions are common among manufacturers, as they aim to combat price advantages from companies based overseas.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Many elevator manufacturers have tried to push for more energy efficient products. Manufacturers aim to make elevators more efficient, supporting the development of artificially intelligent elevators.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as the Internet of Things, in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Some companies have begun developing smart elevators that collect data.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: proper training on the use of machinery and procedure to reduce workplace risks.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Many companies have worked to develop more efficient elevators to reduce energy use.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: The largest companies have relatively high profit. Falling demand from the construction sector negatively impacted profitability.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: When investing in R&D, elevator companies must replace equipment more frequently.
